feed.title: HABits Lab
feed.subtitle: Passibe sensing data analytics- Paving the way towards personalized medicine

entry.title: The HABits Lab Presents Advanced Research in Ubiquitous Computing at ACM Ubicomp 2018

link.title: The HABits Lab Presents Advanced Research in Ubiquitous Computing at ACM Ubicomp 2018

entry.content: PhD Students from The Health Aware Bits (HABits) Lab presented their new work, which focuses on cultivating a healthy lifestyle assisted by technology at the 2018 ACM International Joint Conference on Pervasive and Ubiquitous Computing (UBICOMP 2018). The event was held at the Suntec Singapore Convention and Exhibition Center (colocated with ISWC 2018) October 9-11th in Singapore.: full story
entry.summary: PhD Students from The Health Aware Bits (HABits) Lab presented their new work, which focuses on cultivating a healthy lifestyle assisted by technology at the 2018 ACM International Joint Conference on Pervasive and Ubiquitous Computing (UBICOMP 2018). The event was held at the Suntec Singapore Convention and Exhibition Center (colocated with ISWC 2018) October 9-11th in Singapore.: full story

entry.title: HABits Lab Students Achieve Best Paper Award at 2016 BODYNETS

link.title: HABits Lab Students Achieve Best Paper Award at 2016 BODYNETS

entry.content: Their research focuses on using wrist-worn sensors to detect & count fine grained activity (feeding gestures) using a passive sensing data analytic framework: full story
entry.summary: Their research focuses on using wrist-worn sensors to detect & count fine grained activity (feeding gestures) using a passive sensing data analytic framework: full story

entry.title: Eli Cohen Wins Poster at The Obesity Society

link.title: Eli Cohen Wins Poster at The Obesity Society

entry.content: The research presentation, titled, “Random Forest Detects Eating in Neck-worn Sensor” was well received and further expanded the role of passive sensing in obesity-related research: full story
entry.summary: The research presentation, titled, “Random Forest Detects Eating in Neck-worn Sensor” was well received and further expanded the role of passive sensing in obesity-related research: full story
